A third treaty in the time of Pyrrhus (13.0. 279) provided for an alliance of an offensive and defensive nature in which Carthago was to lend its lieet, but maintained the restrictione on free trade. So far it has been seen that Sicily was regarded as commer- eially a neutral ground between the powers, but it was soon to be their battle field. The long struggle for the possession of the island had greatly weakened Syracuse and ruined most of the Greek cities. One of the few that were still left standing, Messana, was seized by a lawless band of Campanian soldiers turned freebooters, who followed a course that had been popular of late at Rhegium and elsewhere. There they were soon attacked by Hiero, who, first as general, then as king, had lately trained to order the turbulent populace of Syracuse, and revived the dignity of the Sicilian Greeks. Hard pressed by the besiegers the Mamer· tini, ‘men of Mara'as the free lances called themselves, could only baffle Hiero by turning to Carthago or to Rome, and rival parties in the city made overtures to each.
